Keywords: Electronics cooling Tilted system Phase change material Nanoparticles, melting Natural convection Heat generation source Fins Numerical results
The use of materials such as paraffin is widespread in modern energy industries. The ability to absorb a large amount of energy during a phase transition at a constant temperature conditions allows to store and transport the heat. The intensity of melting is related to the thermophysical characteristics of the material and the geometric parameters of the system. Heat transfer inside the system is carried out due to the heat conduction, while in the melt the convective heat transfer intensifies the process. In this paper, a numerical study of heat transfer inside a domain filled with paraffin with nanoparticles and heated from a source of constant volumetric heat generation is performed. A two-dimensional model of the melting process has been formulated in the dimensionless variables ‘‘stream function–vorticity– temperature”, taking into account the natural convective heat transfer occurring in the melt. The system of partial differential equations has been solved using the finite difference method. The simulation has been carried out at different inclination angles of the considered system. Local and integral characteristics of the melting process at different heating levels of the system have been obtained.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Growth of energy consumption in the modern world is inextricably related to the growth of performance of computer technology. In this connection, economical and most effective ways of transporting and storing energy are required. One way of improving energy efficiency is the latent heat thermal storage [1–4], this suggests a using of phase change materials as a chargeable material, which can absorb and generate the energy by liquid-solid phase transition. Various types of phase change materials have recently found application in the development of solar collectors, photovoltaic elements and thermal storage of buildings.
In recent years, the problems of cooling and thermal control have been given great attention in scientific literature [5–8]. Thus, Hajare et al. [9] conducted experimental studies on solar water heating system with paraffin wax enhanced by Al2O3 nanoparticles. Intense in heat transfer rate by addition of nanoparticles was analyzed. Enhancement in the heat transfer due to addition of nanoparticles is most pronounced in the melt because of particles movement. Numerical investigation of heat transfer inside photovoltaic panel based on phase change materials RT25 was car-
ried out by Nehari et al. [10]. The influence of inclination of cavity on the melting process was analyzed. The angle was varied from 0 (then the system was in horizontal position and was heated from the top). It was shown that convective mode in the PCM prevails over conduction at an inclination less than 45 . At horizontal position of cavity in melt fraction the natural convection is absent completely. Mahdi and Nsofor [11] conducted numerical investigation on heat transfer during solidification of PCM with nanoparticles inside the triplex tube. The particle volumetric concentration was varied from 0% to 8%. It was shown that the 8% loading reduces the solidification time by 20%. In the bottom part the solidification process is more intensive because of free convective descending flows of cold melt. Huang et al. [12,13] experimentally and numerically studied of heat transfer in PCM for using in building construction for temperature control in photovoltaic panel. The convective flows inside the melt allow to increase in heat transfer. The finning profile from aluminum also enhances heat transfer, but the fins restrict the circulation of melting material [13]. Temperature control of PV panel integrated in building was studied experimentally by Sharma et al. [14]. Thermal management was carried out by using nano-enhanced PCM and aluminum plate with microfins. It was experimentally shown that in the micro-finned system it is possible to reduce the temperature of aluminum plate by 15.9% by using a pure PCM and by 18.5% by using PCM enhanced by CuO nanoparticles.

Another consequence of increasing energy consumption is the need to develop high-performance and reliable cooling systems. Passive cooling in electronic systems can be provided with metal inserts with a high coefficient of thermal conductivity [15,16]. Using of PCMs in thermal management of electronic devices allows to design the passive cooling systems in a wide range of power and dimensions. In recent years many numerical and experimental studies are devoted to the heat transfer in heat sinks based on phase change materials [17–20]. Experimental study of neicosane melting inside finned aluminum heat sinks was carried out by Fok et al. [17]. The experiments were carried out for four cases, namely, heat sink without PCM, heat sink filled with paraffin and the heat sinks with three fins and with six fins filled with PCM. It was shown that the using of PCM allows to slowing increase the temperature. In the finned heat sink the more intensive heat dissipation was observed. Metal finning profiles of various shapes are used for cooling of electronic equipment. A metal profiles with and without fins filled with paraffin were considered. Experimental study of melting and solidification of n-eicosane in aluminum heat sink with different amount of fins was carried out by Setoh et al. [18]. Despite the rapid melting of the material (less than an hour) under operating conditions of the device from 3 to 5 W, the solidification process takes a much longer time, which is due to the rather low thermal conductivity of paraffin.
Currently there are not many studies, devoted to behavior of nano-enhanced phase change materials within cooling systems. An inclusion of nanoparticles to the material, on one side, increases the thermal conductivity, on the other side, increases the viscosity of the melt. Therefore, for a more complete understanding of the heat transfer process, a multiparameter numerical analysis of the heat transfer process in a material through simulation of the melting process and taking into account natural convection in the melt is necessary. A detailed study of the complex process of interaction of energy transfer mechanisms is practically impossible to carry
out experimentally, therefore numerical problems of heat transfer in materials during phase transitions are actual for today [21–24].
The arrangement of PCM heat sinks in various electronic systems is always related to architecture of the device, because of the need for thermal insulation of the elements between each other and the compact arrangement of all elements. Using of PCM based heat sinks in portable devices is also associated with changes in the position and tilt of the entire system. In this connection, there is a necessity to study performance of system at different inclination angles. At the same time, an analysis of the inclination angle effect is necessary for understanding the melting behavior taking into account various orientation of electronic systems.
Present work is devoted to the numerical study of the conjugate heat and mass transfer in a passive cooling system, designed on the basis of the nano-enhanced phase change material and copper profile with finning. To describe the conjugate heat transfer process, the transformed dimensionless variables such as stream function, vorticity and temperature have been used. Numerical analysis of the complex effect of inclination angle of the system and the concentration of nanoparticles on the melting process of paraffin in conditions of natural convection has been carried out. The present study is a continuation of the previous analysis [24] to the case of inclination angle effect. It is well-known that the tilted systems can be more effective from heat transfer performance point of view [25–27].

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussions
sections.text:
In general the phase change materials like paraffin, have a low thermal conductivity and the melt agitation permits to intensify the heat transfer. Therefore, natural convection has a significant role in melting process in a macrovolumes with measurable temperature differences. The melt agitation is of great importance in the heat transfer from the heater to the interphase at large distances between these boundaries. However, the position of the heating element, intensity of heat generation and the size of considered system have a great influence on the development of the convective mode in the melt. When the entire system is tilted, the position of the heater is changed and accordingly the ratio between convective heat transfer and heat conduction can be changed also [27–29].
The addition of the nanoparticles with high thermal conductivity is a way to increase the heat transfer rate in paraffin. At the same time, the expedience of using of nano-enhanced paraffin associated with a growth of the viscosity of this suspension.
The present investigation includes detailed numerical analysis of complex influence of such parameters as intensity of natural convective heat transfer, inclination of the system and the concentration of nanoparticles in paraffin on the heat dissipation quality of the passive cooling system. The Rayleigh number varied in the range between 1.49 105 and 9.52 106, the inclination angle a
ranged from 0 to p and the loadings of nanoparticlesU varied from 0 to 0.06.
The intensity of convective heat transfer can be determined by the Rayleigh number. Other factors affecting the occurrence of thermogravitational flows in this problem are the size of melt region, temperature of the heater which are time-dependent and increase with time.
At small Rayleigh numbers the natural convection is weak compared to the thermal conductivity. In such modes of heat transfer, the thermal conductivity of the material plays an important role. Therefore, the melting rate will strongly depend on the percentage of nanoparticles in the paraffin. Fig. 3 shows isotherms and streamlines at Ra = 1.49 105 and different cavity inclination angles for a fixed time s = 933.24. Despite a significant rebuilding of the flow, the isotherms have a similar structure for different directions of the gravity vector. The difference can be explained by the fact that the weak ascending streams of the heated liquid promote heating and faster melting in the upper part of the region. Therefore, the most intense melting is observed when a = 0 . The boundary of the phase transition has a wavy formwith vertices above the edges. Also, a weak circulation helps to cool the space between the edges and thicken the isotherms, in contrast to the case of a = 180 in which the liquid over the heat sink overheats more strongly by reducing the flow rates. At Ra = 1.49 105, the addition of nanoparticles to the paraffin contributes to a decrease in the time for complete melting (see Table 2) for all the considered cavity inclination angles. Taking into account these data, it can be concluded that at small Rayleigh numbers the addition of particles promotes rapid heat transfer inside the material and the melting process.

Moreover, the addition of nanoparticles has practically no effect on the flow structure, so the isotherms and isolines of the stream function have a similar structure, although the maximum value of the stream function is reduced to 40%.
As it has been shown, natural convection plays an important role in heat transfer and the melting behavior of the material. In this connection, the direction of the gravitational vector plays an equally important role. Therefore, it is necessary to analyze an influence of inclination angle of the whole system on the thermal processes occurring within the system.
Fig. 4 presents the isotherms and streamlines at different inclination angles of the cavity and different percentages of nanoparticles inside paraffin at Ra = 9.52 106. It is obvious that in the transition from the horizontal position, when the heat source is at the bottom, the melting rate decreases. In the considered range of U, it can be seen that at a fixed time s = 5090.4 the maximum inclination angle reflects weak melting of the paraffin. At a = 0, an insignificant amount of solid material is remained in the upper corners of the paraffin area. Thermal plumes from the middle ribs are directed vertically upward and vortices are drawn along the fins of the heat sink, from the side fins the heated liquid descends along the descending flow from the neighboring vorticity, the thermal and hydrodynamic patterns are observed symmetrically. At the same time, when the area is tilted by p/2 an absolute change in the structure of the flow in the melt is observed. Heated melt flows are directed to the right side wall along the heat sink surface. A cold descending flow is observed along the phase-transition line. Recirculation zones are formed between the ribs closer to the melt boundary. It can be seen from Fig. 4b that, due to convective heat transfer, the right-hand side of the region heats up faster and the boundary of the phase transition in the right-hand side of reached the upper cooling wall, while in the left part of the cavity the boundary moves more slowly, which is a consequence of the motion of the cooled melt, the temperature of which is close to the phase changing temperature. It should be also noted that the most heated zone in the metal heat sink expands to the right, due to a more intense heating of the right side of the area.
Fig. 5 shows the average Nusselt number on the profile surface and the relative volume of the melt as a function of time for various inclination angles of the cavity and nanoparticle concentration at Ra = 1.19 106. From the graph of the average Nusselt number, it can be seen that the process of heating the system and melting the NePCM is complex and involves several stages. At the same time, it should be noted that at the initial stage of heating s 1000 the Nu and Vliq do not depend on the angle of inclination of the cavity and the graphs are coincided. During the heating of the profile to the temperature Tf and during the phase transition on the surface of the profile the Nu plot shows that the dashed line corresponding to the largest particle concentration is below the solid line corresponding to the pure paraffin. In comparison, for
example, on a time interval of a sharp jump in the heat transfer coefficient at the point s = 321.54, the Nusselt number in pure paraffin reaches a value of 1, while at U = 0.06 Nu = 0.8804. This difference becomes clearly visible when the melting boundary moves away from the metal surface and the heat transfer coefficient ceases to increase sharply. At this stage it can be seen that the graphs slowly decrease, due to warming up melted paraffin on the surface due to thermal conduction. Thermal conductivity increases with increasing U, therefore the temperature gradient on the surface of the heat sink is lower than in the case of pure paraffin. Taking into account that convection appears with an expansion of the melt region and at the initial stage the convective heat transfer is very weak, the direction of the gravitational force vector has practically no effect on heat transfer. In this regard, the slope angle does not affect the heat transfer and the Nusselt number and Vliq graphs practically coincide or differ insignificantly for Vliq 0.5.
With the appearance and development of convective flows in the melt, the angle of inclination of the cavity begins to play an important role in relation to the movement of the energy source. When the area is heated from below (a = 0, black lines), as expected, convection will develop more intensively and the heat flux on the surface of the profile will increase. In the inverted position at a = 180, as one would expect, convection practically disappears, since the energy source is in the upper part of the system above the cavity with the heat sink and paraffin. Heat transfer is carried out mainly due to heat conduction. One of the consequences is a strong heating of paraffin between the fins, where the isotherms are stretched horizontally, in connection with this, the temperature gradient is significantly reduced. Melt circulation emerging because of the heating vertically standing ribs is very weak and the intensity of heat exchange between the profile and paraffin significantly decreases. As a consequence, the melting rate is significantly reduced. It should be also noted the effect of the volume fraction of nanoparticles at different angles of the cavity presented in Table 2.
From Table 2 it is seen that for Ra = 1.19 106 and Ra = 9.52 106 the longest melting is observed at an inclination angle a = 135 , and in the cases of 90 and 180 the time of complete melting differs not strongly and in some cases the paraffin melts longer at 90 . This is due to the peculiarity of the formed hydrodynamic structures and the presence of a cooling wall. In the case where the energy source is on top, the cooling wall is located horizontally below and since the circulation of the melt is practically absent, the cooling occurs evenly along the entire perimeter of the wall, which is in contact with the environment. In the case of an inclination of 90 and 135 , the cold descending flow is formed along the wall in contact with the external environment. Cooling harder, the liquid descends into the lower corner. Thus, paraffin in this corner melts much more slowly, which is the reason for a significant increase in the melting time.
Fig. 6 shows the isotherms for different angles of inclination of the cavity at Ra = 1.19 106 and s = 2121. Typical ascending streams from heated ribs are observed at a = 0, in this case it is clearly seen

The addition of particles leads to an increase in viscosity and, with the horizontal position of the cavity, it is seen that the weakening of natural convective currents leads to overheating of the regions around the profile and a decrease in the heat transfer coefficient. As a consequence, the process of melting is slower than in pure paraffin. In contrast to the case with a small Rayleigh number, in the case when convection in the melt plays a significant role in heat transfer, the inclination angle determines the heat and mass transfer regime and the efficiency of the system. When the cavity is tilted by an angle a = 45, the melt descends along the melting front, and one major vortex is formed between each of the adjacent edges, while heating, the liquid rises along the right edge and the descending flow occurs along the left edge. The displacement of the upward-downward currents and the transition from the twovortex circulation to the one-vortex in each compartment leads to the fact that the paraffin warms up more with increasing the slope of the region. The decrease in heat transfer occurs mainly in the lower part of the profile. Despite the increase in the maximum value of the stream function, comparedwith a = 0, the total melting time is increased. Also note the formation of small recirculation currents at a = 45 and U = 0, which also increase the overheating of these zones. A further rise of the inclination angle leads to an even greater overheating of the surface of the profile, since vortices merge and the velocity of the convective currents decreases.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
In this paper a detailed numerical analysis of time-dependent melting of paraffin, enhanced by Al2O3 nanoparticles, in a passive cooling system was carried out. The main attention was paid to the effect of both the system inclination angle and the nanoparticles concentration on melting at different intensities of convective heat and mass transfer. The velocity and temperature distributions are obtained, as well as the curves for the average Nusselt number and the volume of the melt as a function of time.
As a result of detailed analysis it was shown that at small Rayleigh numbers, the addition of nanoparticles to paraffin does not have the significant effect on the hydrodynamic structures in the melt, but the velocities in the melt are significantly reduced. In connection with the dominance of heat conduction as the main mechanism of heat transfer, an increase in the viscosity of the melt caused by the addition of particles does not greatly affect the melting intensity. It can be concluded that the addition of nanoparticles makes it possible to accelerate the process of heat exchange within the system and to reduce the time for complete melting of paraffin at any inclination of the cavity. Depending on the direction of the buoyancy force vector and the intensity of convective heat transfer, nanoparticles can accelerate the melting process or slow down. For large Rayleigh numbers, convective flows have the significant impact on heat and mass transfer, therefore change in melt viscosity with the addition of particles reduces the rates of natural convective flows and leads to overheating of the paraffin near the surface of the slab and, as a result, to a decrease in the heat transfer coefficient at the heat sink surface. Therefore, for small inclinations of the cavity, when convective heat transfer dominates, an increase in the nanoparticles volume fraction leads to an increase in the melting time. A change in the angle of inclination of more than 90 is associated with the movement of the source to the upper part of the region, so the flows are weaker and NePCM melts faster than the pure paraffin.
